Tectonic evolution of the equatorial South Atlantic
Article  in  Geophysical Monograph Series · January 2000

CITATIONS
270

READS
2,468
1 author:
Renato Darros de Matos
Níon Energia
25 PUBLICATIONS   1,132 CITATIONS
SEE PROFILE
Tectonic Evolution of the Equatorial South Atlantic
Renato M. Darros de Matos

Petrobras- 
E&P-RNCE, Natal- RN- Brazil 59074-600

The Brazilian and West African Equatorial margins comprise an unique exam- 
ple of a transform margin, characterized 
by a series of on- and offshore Meso- 
zoic-Cenozoic basins, distributed over 2,200 km along the South Atlantic. Al- 
though a multi-stage stretching process evolved throughout the Aptian- 
Cenomanian, an almost instantaneous 
Aptian stage was responsible for a wide- 
spread fracturing of the Equatorial Atlantic. Conventional extensional processes 
can not explain the kinematics and rift geometry of the Equatorial SouthAtlantic 
basins. Accepted pure-shear or simple-shear rift mechanisms, 
typical of diver- 
gent margins, cannot be promptly used in basins generated as a response to major 
transform motions along a continental-scale 
plate boundary. The commonly ac- 
cepted causal processes for rifting, such as passive/active or diffuse/discrete 
rifting, can not accommodate 
the South Atlantic Equatorial data set. Even though 
shearing signatures and pull-apart features are easily recognized throughout the 
margin, their magnitude and basin architecture varies significantly as a function 
of the distance from the main transform faults. These factors resulted in signifi- 
cant differences in thermal evolution, tectonic subsidence, facies distribution and 
uplift history. The tectonic evolution of the sedimentary 
basins along the Equato- 
rial Atlantic is better understood by considering three stages: pre, syn and post- 
transform movements. These are related to kinematic and dynamic controls pro- 
vided by the emplacement of fractured swells as proto mid ocean ridges, fol- 
lowed by the creation of oceanic crust and the onset of transform shearing be- 
tween Africa 
and Brazil.
INTRODUCTION

Active transform margins are characterized by sharp 
topographic differences between ocean and continent, 
which are defined by active strike-slip faulting, a poorly 
developed shelf, and very deep sedimentary basins 
(Mascle, 1976; Twiss and Moores, 1992; Basile et al.,

1993). The Equatorial Atlantic provide may provide a very 
good example of an ancient transform margin with a long

Atlantic Rifts and Continental Margins 
Geophysical Monograph 115 
Copyright 2000 by the American Geophysical Union

history of transform movements, leading to the develop- 
ment of very complex sedimentary basins on each side of 
the ocean (Figures 1 and 2). These basins are characterized 
by multiple subsidence phases and associated structural
styles.

The stepwise opening of the South Atlantic resulted in 
considerable diachronic deformation in the Equatorial and 
eastern Brazilian margins, recorded in the northern and 
northeastern portion of Brazil as a series of magmatic and

sedimentary events. While the eastern Brazilian margin 
and the central portion of the Western African margin had 
a longer rift stage (Neocomian-Barremian), the stretching 
stage in the Equatorial Margin was shorter. During the 
Aptian stage, an almost instantaneous 
period of oblique
332 EQUATORIAL SOUTH ATLANTIC
Africa

Figure 1: South America and Africa at present and about 90 
Mybp. Continuous lines between Africa and South America rep- 
resent gravity / topographic anomalies, interpreted as fracture 
zones based on Geosat gravity map of Sandwell & Smith (1995).

extension was responsible for a widespread fracturing of 
the Equatorial Atlantic, even though a multi-stage stretch- 
ing process evolved throughout the Aptian-Cenomanian 
interval.

The well-known divergent margin rift architecture, 
commonly defined by tilted half-grabens, with depocenters 
controlled by planar/listric faults, and filled with a diver- 
gent wedge of siliciclastics sediments, normally with fan- 
glomerates adjacent to the main border fault, are not 
promptly recognized in the Equatorial margin domain. In 
many cases it is difficult to recognize a divergent seismic 
pattern in the rift sequence, as illustrated in the offshore 
Potiguar and Cearfi basins in Brazil, where conglomerates 
and even coarse to medium-grained alluvial sediments may 
be missing adjacent to main border faults. Another major 
difference between the transform and the divergent margin 
segments of the South Atlantic includes the lack of a sig- 
nificant pre-rift section, as well as a transitional evaporitic 
section between the rift and drift stages. Local tectonics 
and magmatism had a key role in the post-break up, ther- 
mal subsidence phase. Abrupt variations in the temporal 
and spatial location of magmatism as well as the spatial 
distribution of releasing and restraining bends through the 
region led to a quite different drift stage from basin to ba- 
sin. Another key factor was deformation rate.

The purpose of this paper is to provide an overview of 
the tectono-stratigraphic 
evolution of the Equatorial Bra- 
zilian Margin, and its African counterpart, as well as to 
discuss a kinematic model to describe the Atlantic opening

(Figure 2). Emphasis is placed on the interpretation of 
three-dimensional geometries of the basins, and particu- 
larly, in the description of their structural styles and tec- 
tono-stratigraphic sequences.

The Equatorial portion of the Brazilian Margin encom- 
pass a series of offshore basins, from east to west, the Po- 
tiguar, Cear•, Barreirinhas, Par•-Maranh•o and Foz do 
Amazonas (Figures 2, 3, and 4), some of which extend to 
the onshore (e.g. the Potiguar and Barreirinhas basins). 
Among them, there are three aborted riffs: (1) the onshore 
Potiguar graben, (2) the Maraj6 basin (Mexiana, Limoeiro 
and Gurup/t grabens) and (3) Gurupi Graben System (Sgo 
Luis, Braganq;a Viseu and Ilha Nova grabens; Azevedo,
1991) as illustrated in Figures 4, 5 and 6.

The Equatorial African margin consists of a series of 
open marine basins that make up the northern part of the 
Gulf of Guinea (Figure 2), with a wide variety of mostly 
offshore basins, named, from west to east: The Sierra Le- 
one-Liberia, C6te-D'Ivoire-Ghana (Tano-Salt Pond-Accra- 
Keta basins, Figures 2, 4 and 5), the Dohomey Embayment 
(Togo-Benin-western 
Nigeria basins, Figures 2, and 6) hnd 
Benue Trough/Niger Delta (Figure 6). The entire region 
was developed under the kinematic influence of the St. 
Paul, Romanche and Chain Fracture Zones, with a special 
influence of the Romanche Fracture zone, which kept a 
much longer history of transform movements between the 
C6te d'Ivoire-Ghana margin and the abyssal plain of the 
Gulf of Ghinea, as illustrated in Figure 7, a Santonian re- 
construction 
of the Equatorial South Atlantic.

Main Physiographic Features of the Equatorial Brazilian 
Continental Margin

The physiography of the Brazilian Equatorial margin is 
characterized by a relatively narrow shelf on the eastern 
side, between 30 and 50 km wide, broadening towards 
west, where the shelf-width ranges between 50 and 300 
kmo A key feature is the Amazon Cone, a 900 by 400 km 
sedimentary feature, cut by canyons, fed by the Amazon 
river (Figure 3). The shelf break is characterized by a 
steeper slope, in general at depths between 50 and 2000 
meters. Several submarine canyons cut deeply into the 
continental shelf down to the abyssal plain. Another im- 
portant feature of the Brazilian Equatorial Atlantic is the 
presence of many seamounts 
or guyots, related to fracture 
zones and / or hot-spots tracks.

TECTONO- 
STRATIGRAPHIC 
EVOLUTION:

Deformation associated with the South Atlantic opening 
began during Jurassic-Triassic 
time (225-160 Ma), as re-

Figure 3. Main features of the equatorial Brazilian continental margin, as illustrated by enhanced gravity anomalies 
from Geosat data (provided by D. Sandwell). Topography is shown onshore. Lineaments are due to anomalies weaker 
or stronger than the normal gravity field.

corded by magmatic events and sedimentation 
in southern 
and northern Brazil. However, the major rifting event oc- 
curred considerably later, during the Cretaceous (160-115 
Ma). Rifting has been dated as Early Cretaceous (Neoco- 
mian-Barremian time) in the southern South Atlantic, and 
slightly younger in the Equatorial Atlantic (Aptian-Albian- 
Cenomanian), when transtensional conditions prevailed 
throughout the Equatorial domain. Seawaters from the 
Equatorial and southern Atlantic Oceans only mixed dur- 
ing mid to late Albian (Koutsoukos, 1992), dating the final 
separation 
between the South America and Africa. 
Figure 8 is a composite image of stratigraphic columns 
of the Brazilian side of the Equatorial Atlantic, illustrating 
the lack of known pre-Aptian (syn-stretching) 
sediments in 
the Equatorial Atlantic, with the exception of the eastern 
and westernmost basins of the Brazilian Equatorial Atlan- 
tic margin, which recorded diachronous deformations as- 
sociated with the Central Atlantic 
and the Southern Atlan- 
tic, respectively. The Potiguar basin is a key segment of 
the Equatorial margin because it is part of a series of ini- 
tially intracontinental rift basins associated with the inter- 
section of the Southern and Equatorial branches of the At-

lantic rift system, developed during the Neocomian (Ma- 
tos, 1992, Figure 6). On the other hand, the Maraj6 basin is 
an older rift system, recording the southernmost 
effect of 
the Triassic-Jurassic 
extension associated 
with the opening 
of the Central Atlantic Ocean, which led to the emplace- 
ment of the Cassipor6 dyke swarm observed on the Guy- 
ana Shield. Late Jurassic extensional-related 
magmatism in 
the proto-Equatorial region occurred in the Borborema 
Province (around the Potiguar basin). It is represented by a 
dyke swarm (the alkaline Rio Cearfi Mirim magmatism; 
Gomes et al., 1981), which yielded K/At ages ranging 
between 150 and 120 Ma (late Jurassic - Neocomian), with 
two peaks of activity at 145 and 130 Ma (Oliveira, 1992). 
Magmatism in the Benue Trough (Africa) is represented 
by 
the Burashika volcanic complex (147 + 7 Ma, K/At, Po- 
poff, 1988) and earlier granitic intrusions of the Jos Pla- 
teau (Nigeria), with Triassic-Jurassic 
ages (213 to 141 Ma 
Rb-Sr, Vail, 1989).

The Paleozoic intracratonic Parnaiba basin recorded ef- 
fusive and intrusive magmatic events, composed of up to 
500 meters of tholeitic basalts of the Sardinha Formation 
within the sedimentary pile, and by intrusive dyke swarms

in the eastern portion of the basin. The oldest magmatic 
event is Late Triassic - Jurassic (Almeida et al, 1988), and 
the second episode correspond to an Early Cretaceous 
event (Caldasso and Hama, 1978), synchronous with the 
Rio Cearfi. Mirim magmatism.

GEODYNAMIC 
MECHANISMS

A controversial issue regarding the tectonic evolution of 
the African and Brazilian Equatorial margins is based on 
the relative importance given to mantle dynamics versus 
plate dynamics (or passive versus active rifting). The Po- 
tiguar basin (Brazil) and Benue Trough (Africa) have been 
used as an example of a triple junction during the break-up 
of the South Atlantic, which implies an active type model 
of basin development. The Brazilian Equatorial margin 
dataset provides a good chronological control of deforma- 
tion and magmatism in transform margins. Rifting is

diachronous, and despite some pre and syn-extension dyke 
intrusions in the Potiguar basin, voluminous magmatism 
clearly post-dates the opening of the Equatorial Atlantic. 
There is a significant time-lag for the onset of rifting be- 
tween the Potiguar basin and the Benue Trough (Matos,

1992). By the time extensional deformation started in 
Benue, the onshore Potiguar basin and a series of intracon- 
tinental rift basins of Brazil (Cariri-Potiguar rift valley) 
were already aborted. The issue of a pre-rift uplift is also 
controversial because of the long term epirogenetic re- 
sponse of the Borborema Province / Nigerian Shield, 
which correspond to a heritage of the Pan-African / Bra- 
siliano orogeny (Azevedo, 1991).

The idea of a hot spot (St. Helena) triggering the onset of 
rifting in the Equatorial Atlantic (O'Connor and Duncan,

1990) is controversial because true evidence for an active 
hot spot in the region comes only from the Tertiary record. 
In order to add corroborative evidence for an active plume 
system, some authors have considered magmatic data from 
distant basins, such as the Cabo basin (Wilson and Gui- 
raud, 1992). However, this basin is located about 500 km 
away from the Potiguar-Benue junction (Figure 6). These 
data would suggest a very broad zone of diffuse volcanism, 
and might provide evidence for a quite broad "mushroom 
head" or extensive underplating. The issue is not whether 
we have enough evidence for an ancient cold weak plume, 
but whether it was strong enough to trigger rifting or it just 
weakened the lithosphere, favoring the concentration of 
stresses in this region, allowing plate tectonic forces to 
play a key role in the process.

The intracontinental 
and offshore basins of the eastern- 
most region of the Equatorial Atlantic can be grouped in 
two ages: Neocomian-Barremian and AptJan. The site and

architecture of the first group of basins were strongly con- 
trolled by upper crustal heterogeneities (Matos, 1992), 
while the second group (AptJan basins in the Equatorial 
Atlantic) were not significantly influenced by the Protero- 
zoic heritage, indicating different processes 
of lithospheric 
thinning between the Equatorial and the Southern 
branches, which could indicate deep-seated processes on 
the Equatorial margin. Equatorial fragmentation 
was a re- 
sponse to stresses induced by plate tectonic forces. These 
were controlled by large-scale lateral movements of the 
crust, triggering transform movements throughout the re- 
gion and climaxing with the complete opening of the South 
Atlantic Ocean. This progressive, 
kinematically driven de- 
formation led to a stack of complex structures on a re- 
gional scale, very different from those found in typical ex- 
tensional terrains.

Conventional 
mechanisms of basin formation cannot be 
promptly used when modeling sedimentary basins gener- 
ated as a response to major transform motions of a conti- 
nental-scale 
plate boundary. The commonly adopted causal 
processes for passive margins, such as passive/active or 
diffuse/discrete rifting, or volcanic/non-volcanic margins 
can not be easily applied in the Equatorial basins. One of 
the biggest challenges in the understanding 
of transform 
margins is the quantification of stretching prior to break- 
up. Another key factor is the deformation rate during the 
syn-transform stage. Divergent margins show relatively 
longer rifting stages (between 10 and 25 Ma in the eastern 
Brazilian Margin) prior to break up, allowing lithospheric 
stretching at reasonable rates, resulting in mantle decom- 
pression and in some cases the outpouring of continental 
flood basalts. Although this multi-stage rifting process in 
the Brazilian/African Equatorial margin evolved through- 
out the Aptian-Cenomanian interval, an almost instantane- 
ous AptJan rift stage was responsible for the widespread 
fracturing of the Equatorial Atlantic (Figure 8). Stretching 
prior to sea-floor spreading was very fast (AptJan time), 
with no evidence of volcanic margins in the sense defined 
in orthogonal extensional regimes (White and McKenzie,

1989; White, 1992). These are characterized by syn-rift ig- 
neous activity and also by thick wedges of seaward- 
dipping reflectors marking the transition from continental 
to oceanic crust (Hinz, 1981).

The tectonic evolution of the Equatorial Atlantic is better 
understood if considering three stages: pre, syn and post- 
transform movements (Figure 9). A multi-stage basin de- 
velopment has been recognized in both sides of the Equa- 
torial Atlantic: a rift stage (AptJan - early Albian) and a 
shear-dominated 
stage (early Albian-Cenomanian), 
as dis- 
cussed by Zal•n and Warme (1985); Azevedo (1991), 
Szatmari et al. (1987), Cremonini et al. (1996), and Gui-

raud et al. (1997). The main unconformities in the sedi- 
mentary succession 
are clearly associated 
with events that 
pre-date, are synchronous 
or post-date the activation of 
transform faults. Mainly on the basis of changes in struc- 
tural style, facies association, inferred deformation rate, 
strain analysis, and plate kinematics studies, the tectonic 
evolution of the Equatorial Atlantic is described consider- 
ing the kinematic and dynamic controls on the activation 
of transform faults, the emplacement of oceanic crust and 
the onset of drifting of Africa and South America, as 
summarized in Figure 9. The three stages associated with 
the development of the Equatorial Atlantic margin are de- 
scribed as follows.
Pre- Transform

The Pre-Transform stage in the Equatorial branch is re- 
corded by two sedimentary cycles: 
(1) Pre-Transtension: Jurassic and early Cretaceous (pre-

Barremian) sediments that pre-date the main stretching 
phase in the Equatorial Atlantic. This phase is repre- 
sented by the rift sediments of the Maraj6 and onshore 
Potiguar basins, and are related to the opening of the 
Central and Southern Atlantic, respectively; 
(2) $yn-Transtension: 
The onset of intracontinental 
shear 
and fracturing under transtensional conditions of the 
Equatorial Atlantic has been dated as late Barremian, 
coeval with the occurrence of the oldest sediments of 
the Benue Trough in Africa (Aptian shales of the 
Bima Formation, Popoff, 1988), and simultaneous 
with late syn-rift stages of the eastern margin (Matos,

t992). Stress in the Equatorial domain began to dissi- 
pate as the entire region started to break apart. 
Transtensional 
conditions created a series of NW-SE 
trending en-echelon depocenters throughout the 
Equatorial domain. This latter stage has been called 
syn-rift. However, these sediments show major devia- 
tions from a classical rift signature, which is charac- 
terized by tilted half-grabens, with depocenters con- 
trolled by planar/listric faults, and normally filled with

a divergent wedge of siliciclastics sediments, with a 
predominance of fanglomerates adjacent to the main 
border fault (Chang et al., 1992). These features are 
not recognized in the Equatorial margin domain. In 
many cases it is difficult to see a divergent seismic 
pattern, as illustrated in the Potiguar and Cearfi basins 
in Brazil and many others equatorial basins (Figures

10 to 14), where conglomerates and even coarse to 
medium grained alluvial sediments may be missing

adjacent to main border faults. In many basins of the 
Equatorial Atlantic, geologic restorations indicate 
relatively wide and shallow "syn-rift" precursory ba- 
sin, which very often resembles a sag-type basin, and 
not a half-grabeno Stratal geometries adjacent to the 
border fault systems characterize either synclines or 
sets of parallel strata dipping basinward, truncated by 
a diffuse fault pattern (Figures 10 to 12). Figure 15 il- 
lustrates schematically typical equatorial Afro- 
Brazilian basin geometries compared with a classical 
rift-basin 
architecture. 
While some basins were generated under pull-apart con- 
ditions, some segments of the margin located on releasing 
bends experienced almost orthogonal extension, which led 
many authors to characterize a rift succession 
throughout 
the transform margin segment. However, the lack of clas- 
sical rift structures and associated sedimentary facies indi- 
cate that this may not be the case for the Brazilian Equato- 
rial margin. Figure 15 illustrates a migrated seismic section 
of the Cearfi basin (Mundafi sub-basin), developed under 
transtensional conditions, which displays an unique border 
fault geometry.

Another major difference between transform and diver- 
gent margins is the lack of an expressive 
pre-rift section, as 
well as an evaporitic transitional section between the rift 
and drift stages, which are common features in the eastern 
Brazilian margin. Detailed pre-drift reconstructions 
dem- 
onstrated diffuse deformation distributed through a 
transtensional 
path in the proto-Equatorial 
region. Basins 
200-250 km wide (Afro-American basins) developed be- 
fore the breakup of Western Gondwana (Figures 4, 5 and 
6). Obliquity of the stress field during the early stages of 
transform motion was a key controlling factor on the re- 
sultant basin architecture.

The rigidity of the West-African/S•.o Luiz Craton in the 
west, and the Transversal Zone (Matos, 1992; Matos and

Waick, 1998) in the east, prevented the onset of transten- 
sional deformation in the Equatorial Atlantic until the early 
Aptian, when the entire equatorial domain began to de- 
velop a series of en-echelon depocenters. 
The Transversal 
Zone is the northernmost and youngest rifted segment of 
the Southern Branch (eastern Brazilian margin), a roughly 
orthogonal structure between the Pernambuco shear zone 
and the Benue Trough (Touros High in Brazil, Figures 2 
and 6), which record a very fast and focused stretching 
phase (5 My, Matos, 1998), responsible for overcoming 
the last link between Africa 
and Brazil. 
This transversal 
zone acted as a giant accommodation 
zone, balancing ex- 
tension between the Southern and the Equatorial branches 
(Matos, 1992).

Figure 13: Line drawings from the Piaui and Ceatfi basins in Brazil, represented 
by the Camocim and Mundafi sub- 
basins. Location in Fig. 2. The Piaui-Camocim 
basin was heavily deformed 
and faulted during the opening of the 
Equatorial 
Atlantic, while the Mundafi sub-basin 
was less deformed 
due to its location in a releasing 
bend of the 
Equatorial shear corridor.
The Albian Transition

The Albian stage encompasses 
a typical transtensional 
sequence 
throughout the Equatorial branch/Benue 
trough 
(Szatmari et al., 1987; Benkhelil, 1989), while a shallow 
carbonate platform megasequence 
was developed in the 
eastern Brazilian Margin (Chang et al., 1988). The Lower 
Albian record display mixed continental / marine environ- 
ments in many equatorial basins, such as Potiguar, Piaui- 
Camocim, and Barreirinhas 
basins, suggesting 
a progres- 
sive marine influence into the region. Deep water plank- 
tonic morphotypes 
of middle Albian age confirm the pres- 
ence of deep oceanic circulation between the Equatorial 
and the eastern margins (Koutsoukos, 
1992), providing 
evidence for the onset of major transform movements in 
the Equatorial Margin.
Syn-Transform

There is a clear boundary between the transtensional 
stage and the syn-transform 
stage. As stretching 
increased
Mantle

and the equatorial transtensional path widened, the litho- 
sphere became increasingly thinned, particularly at some 
releasing bends, where the emplacement of fractured 
swells acted as proto mid-ocean-ridges, 
opening windows 
of oceanic crust in the continental crust. This led to the on- 
set of transform faulting linking the proto-spreading 
cen- 
ters throughout the region, defining a lithospheric bound- 
ary between Africa and South America. This new bound- 
ary forced deformation to become focused at greater 
depths, but probably still with a diffuse signature at shal- 
lower depths, producing distinct styles of deformation at 
different structural levels. Upper crustal heritage was not 
responsible 
for focusing the deformation. Except for some 
local exceptions, the structural fabric of the S•o Luis / 
West African 
cratons and the Brasiliano / Pan-African 
belts of Africa and Brazil did not control the overall ge- 
ometry of the Equatorial margin, which reinforces a lithos- 
pheric / kinematic control on the resultant equatorial trans- 
form margin geometry.

The term wrench is used here to kinematically charac- 
terize an overall tectonic regime (as used by Milne& 1994),

instead of a dynamic meaning as developed by Anderson 
(1942). As expected in wrench tectonics, the structures are 
not evenly distributed along the margin. A regional rota- 
tional strain regime, kinematically controlled, produced 
complex structural patterns, characterized 
by conjugate 
strike-slip fault systems, with associated normal and re- 
verse faults. Oblique slip faults and folded structures of 
many different types, whose orientation and scale are the 
result of simultaneous extension and contraction in the

horizontal plane, are shown in map-view in Figures 4 and 
5.

The Albian reconstruction 
(105 Mybp, Figure 17) pro- 
vides an early view of the final plate boundary, where an 
alternance between straight and curved segments is quite 
obvious, generating major releasing and restraining trans- 
form segments. Deformation partitioning as a function of 
the coaxiality of the progressive 
deformation (Fossen et al, 
1994) in the Equatorial Atlantic led to basin segments 
dominated by transtension 
or transpression. 
The Barreirin- 
has (Tano in Africa) and Mundafi-Potiguar (Keta-Togo- 
Benin in Africa) segments of the Equatorial margin 
evolved under pure shear-dominated 
transtension, 
charac- 
terized by broad regions dominated by extension, limited 
by discrete shear zones, recognized on conventional seis- 
mic data as discrete oblique faults, and flower-structures. 
In the Parfi-Maranhao (C6te-d'Ivoire) and East Potiguar 
(Benue) basins deformation evolved through wrench- 
dominated transtension, where the divergent movement 
was accommodated 
by relatively narrow zones, accounting 
for most of the the slip between Africa and Brazil. A large 
transpressive belt was developed in the Piaui-Camocim- 
Acarafi (Accra) basins as the result of an overall shortening 
and uplift around a left overstep of this dextral transform 
system. This segment evolved under wrench dominated 
transpression, generating major oblique/strike slip faults, 
en echelon folds and shale ridges (Zaldn and Warme,
1985). Figures 18 and 19 show some examples of these
structures.

It is important to note that the direction of tectonic trans- 
port along the entire margin was kinematically controlled 
by the oblique divergent movement of Africa and Brazil, 
as suggested 
by the spreading directions inferred from AI- 
bian reconstructions 
in the Central 
and South Atlantic 
(Pindell et al., 1988; Scotese et al., 1988; Unternehr et al.,

1988). The lithospheric boundary was defined by an array 
of transform faults that provided a network of right over- 
steps (jogs), mechanically responsible 
for accommodating 
this rotational 
deformation. 
Some basins located at the 
heart of major transtensional 
segments 
may display a local 
tectonic style close to a pure extensional basin, such as 
tilted half-grabens, 
and normal faults, as shown in Figure 
12. However, the entire margin was clearly marked by the 
overall obliquity of the movement between Africa and 
Brazil.

Even though shearing signatures and pull-apart features 
are easily recognized throughout the Brazilian Equatorial 
margin, their magnitude and architecture 
vary significantly 
according to the distance from the main transform faults. 
These faults are diachronous 
by nature. As the African and 
South American continents 
progressively 
moved apart, the

..PR .

This kinematically controlled, shear-dominated 
fragmenta- 
tion process led to diachronous 
pseudo-break-up 
uncon- 
formites. This is markedly different from the divergent 
segments of the Southern Atlantic, where the break-up 
unconformity marks the change from a mechanically 
driven subsidence 
(rift stage) to a thermally driven subsi- 
dence (passive margin stage). In the Equatorial Atlantic 
margin, major unconformities 
may not be correlated 
with 
the emplacement 
of the oceanic crust (juxtaposed 
across a 
transform fault) but related to the thermal effect of dy- 
namic features, such as a spreading center, or the devel- 
opment of a new transform 
fault, leading to tectonic uplift 
and heating increase around the fault path.

Cear Basin-Mundaa 
Sub-basin

Figure 16. Migrated seismic section of the Cearfi Basin (Mundafi 
sub-basin- Brazil), illustrating a typical basin architecture devel- 
oped under transtensional 
conditions at a releasing bend of the 
Equatorial Atlantic.

deformation zone became wide, and newly formed trans- 
form faults were generated, leading to a migration of the 
active transform faults towards newly formed active 
spreading centers. Therefore, as this process evolved, some 
newly formed faulted blocks were developed towards the 
active transform fault, while some older basin compart- 
ments became inactive and were sealed by younger sedi- 
ments. This resulted in significant differences between ba- 
sins in terms of their subsidence histories, geometries, and 
facies distributions, according to the distance from an ac- 
tive transform fault and / or any newly active spreading 
center. Moreover, the age for juxtaposition of continental 
crust against oceanic crust across a transform fault will dif- 
fer from basin to basin, according with the lateral distance 
from a spreading center. Shearing of continental crust 
against continental crust on transform faults was kinemati- 
cally controlled. Shearing of continental crust against 
newly formed oceanic crust was strongly influenced by the 
proximity of spreading centers.

In typical divergent passive margins, the drift stage is 
characterized by almost continuous sedimentation as the 
result of cooling and thermal contraction of the lithosphere 
where eustasy played an important role on the final facies 
distribution. Local tectonics and magmatism had a key 
hole in the post-break-up subsidence in the Equatorial 
margin. In the sedimentary basins along the Brazilian 
Equatorial margin, the proximity from a transform fault 
defines when and where a transform margin became a pas- 
sive margin. As the continental shelf of some basins devel- 
oped quite away from any transform fault, these basins 
display basin architecture and facies distribution of typical 
passive margins. However, basins that were developed 
close to and coeval with a transform fault and/or fracture 
zone display a signature of a passive transform margin, or 
a passive margin developed with a strong wrench compo- 
nent. The C6te d' Ivoire-Ghana margin provides a good ex- 
ample of the dynamic evolution of passive transform mar- 
gins, developing diachronous 
marginal ridges between the 
Deep Ivorian Basin and the Gulf of Guinea (Basile et al,

The dynamic juxtaposition of spreading centers against 
the continental margin on the opposite side of a transform 
fault causes heating and thermal uplift (Pierce et al, 1996) 
The thermal uplift was responsible for anomalous stress 
fields, leading to deformation, recorded as important un- 
conformities, which may or may not be amplified by syn- 
cronous eustatic sea level variations. An example of this 
type of uplift has been proposed for the marginal ridge 
along the C6te d'Ivoire-Ghana margin, as described by 
Mascle et al. (1997).

Therefore, local tectonics and magmatism exhibit im- 
portant roles in the "post-break-up" subsidence histories.

MATOS 
349

Another key issue that deserves attention is the use of 
small tilted-blocks as indicators of syn-rift sedimentation. 
This paradigm is not recommended 
in the Equatorial mar- 
gin, because releasing bends associated 
with active trans- 
form faults provided enough opportunities 
to develop nor- 
mal faults and pull-apart sub-basins, even long after 
stretching ceased. During the process of strain concentra- 
tion, new sets of roughly E-W trending strike-slip fault 
systems were developed by the basinward migration of ac- 
tive transform faults, overprinting the previously deposited 
sediments, above either continental or oceanic crust, identi- 
fied on seismic lines as flower-structures, folds and/or up- 
lifted tilted blocks.
The Passive Transform Margin- $yn-Transform

1993). This process indicates an ocean-ward migration of 
active transform faults through time, leading to local tec- 
tonic uplifts, heating increases and often local unconfor-

mities. Thermal exchanges between the continental crust of 
the Ivorian 
basin and the oceanic crust of the Gulf 
of 
Guinea resulted in a marginal ridge uplift about 130 km 
long (Guiraud et al, 1997). On both sides of the Equatorial 
Atlantic, the progressive ocean-ward migration of active 
transform faults left behind a series of ridges, bouded by 
oblique to strike-slip faults, very often interpreted as nor- 
mal faults, covered by a wedge of younger, siliciclastic to 
carbonatic, platformal sediments. The 84 My reconstruc- 
tion of Figure 7 indicates an assymetric distribution of 
spreading center between Africa and Brazil, clearly close 
to Africa, which explains the continuous influence of the 
Romanche 
Fracture 
Zone 
over the C6te d'Ivoire-Ghana 
segment of the African margin (Mascle and Bas#e, 1997).
Post- Transform - Passive Margin

A typical passive margin environment is only reached 
after the thermal effect of any nearby spreading center is 
finished; and the tectonic influence of a fracture zone / 
transform fault becomes a minor control on the available 
space generated by the thermal cooling of the lithosphere 
and sea level variations. The subsidence curves of trans- 
form margin segments indicate a flattening of the tectonic 
component of the total subsidence during the post- 
transform stage. However, some segments of the Equato- 
rial margin are affected by large sedimentary input associ- 
ated with deltas that prograded from the platform toward 
deep water region (e.g., Amazon cone and the Niger delta).

The upper portions of these deltas are characterized 
by 
extensional, 
gravity-driven 
tectonics, 
whereas

of the progradational 
wedge is characterized

CONCLUSIONS

The integrated 
analysis 
of the South American 
and Afri- 
can equatorial 
basins 
may provide important 
clues regard- 
ing the kinematic evolution of transform 
margins. The 
opening of the equatorial 
Atlantic was dynamically 
con- 
trolled by lithospheric 
stresses, 
resulting 
in complex dis- 
placements 
throughout 
the margin. This dynamic element 
of lithospheric 
deformation 
produced 
an unique segment 
among the Circum-Atlantic 
basins, 
which can not be ade- 
quately explained 
by conventional 
extensional 
processes, 
such as passive 
or active rifting, or by mechanisms 
such as 
pure-shear 
or simple-shear, 
typical of divergent 
margins.

MATOS 
351

For example, the Brazilian and African data set do not cor- 
roborate the idea of a plume-generated 
triple junction over 
the easternmost 
portion of the Equatorial 
Atlantic. Rifting 
was diachronous between the Benue and Potiguar basins, 
and voluminous 
magmatism 
clearly post-dated 
the opening 
of the Equatorial Atlantic.

The fragmentation 
process 
started as diffuse magmatic 
and sedimentary 
events, which began in Late Barremian 
time, with the initiation of lithospheric stretching in the 
equatorial 
Atlantic, triggered 
by the onset of transtensional 
deformation. This event climaxed during the Aptian, when 
almost instantaneous extension was responsible for the 
widespread 
fracturing of the Equatorial 
Atlantic, generat- 
ing relatively wide and shallow precursory 
basins, 
with no 
evidence of volcanic margins or widespread development 
of typical syn-rift basins, as expected 
in orthogonal 
exten- 
sional regimes. The equatorial 
splitting evolved during the 
Albian-Cenomanian interval, through a multi-stage basin 
development, 
which is better understood 
if the kinematic

Figure 19: Migrated seismic section from the Piaui-Camocim Basin in Brazil. Location in Fig. 5. Seismic signature of 
strike-slip faults associated with the Arianrico High and the Romanche Fracture Zone.

and dynamic controls are considered 
along 'with the 
chronologic activation of transform faults, the emplace- 
ment of oceanic crust and the onset of drifting between Af- 
rica and South America. The geodynamic evolution on the 
Equatorial Atlantic is addressed by recognizing tectonic 
stages that pre-date, are synchronous 
or post-date the acti- 
vation of transform faults in the Equatorial Atlantic.

Prior to the activation 
of transform 
faulting, transten- 
sional 
conditions 
created 
a series of en-echelon 
basins 
throughout the Equatorial domain, referred to here as a 
syn-stretching phase. The term syn-rift is avoided due to 
major deviations from a classical rift signature. The basin 
architectures observed in most of the Equatorial margin are 
usually characterized by the lack of expressive divergent 
wedges of sediments next to the main border fault systems, 
even though some basins generated under pull-apart con- 
ditions. The Albian Stage recorded a diachronous transi- 
tion from transtensional (shallow) deformation to deep- 
seated deformational processes, represented by the activa-

0 
5 krn

tion of transform faults, and the emplacement of oceanic 
crust, defining the lithospheric boundary between Africa 
and South America. The boundary geometry was con- 
trolled by an array of transform faults that provided a net- 
work of right oversteps, which evolved to major releasing 
and restraining transform segments, kinematically con- 
trolled by the oblique divergent movement of Africa and 
Brazil. A regional rotational strain regime, kinematically 
controlled, produced complex structural patterns, unevenly 
distributed in the Equatorial branch, a characteristic of the 
wrench tectonics structural style. The resultant deformation 
was partitioned into domains dominated by pure-shear or 
wrench dominated transtension 
and/or transpression. 
Local tectonics and magmatism played a key role in the 
"post-break-up" subsidence. The resultant basin architec- 
ture, facies distribution and subsidence history for any 
particular basin vary significantly according to its paleo- 
geographic position and to its proximity to active trans- 
form faults. The dynamic juxtaposition of continental crust

against 
oceanic 
r'r•qt or qnreadino 
centerq 
on the ormosite 
side of a transform fault caused diachronous deformations, 
recorded on the sedimentary record as important uncon- 
formities, amplified or not by synchronous 
eustatic sea 
level variations.
